awd_titl_txt: Controlling secondary flows by the use of non-wetting surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Turbulent secondary flows are naturally or artificially induced flows perpendicular to the main direction of primary flow.  Many important industrial processes have curved-pipe systems and rotating machinery designed to enhance and optimize mixing of chemicals and other fluids.  These systems may also produce turbulent secondary flows. Depending on how the secondary flow is generated, it may be ordered and stationary in space creating stagnant regions, which inhibits mixing even if the flow has significant turbulence. This research will provide a better understanding of the physics behind the generation of secondary flows and how to control them.  Computations and experiments will be used to investigate using non-wetting (hydrophobic) surfaces to impact and control these flow features.  Every summer, a camp will be held for more than 30 underrepresented minority K-12 students to encourage STEM.

The goal of this project is to investigate the use of non-wetting surfaces to induce, affect, and control secondary flows through selectively patterning the solid boundaries. By using a combination of direct numerical simulations and laboratory experiments, questions on which types and patterns of treatments are most effective the secondary flows. The effectiveness of different kinds of surface treatments, both in the direction of the flow, and perpendicular to the flow, will be evaluated by measuring frictional losses and flow homogeneity. Investigations will be based on a canonical system where pinned secondary flows are known to exist, namely Taylor-Couette turbulence, i.e. the flow between two concentric cylinders. Simulations will be carried out to test a wide variety of surface patterns to determine the most efficient arrangements by using boundary conditions that resemble both ideal and real treatments. Experiments will measure the real-world efficacy of these treatments with great precision. Finally, by studying aging surfaces, the lifetime of the treatment effectiveness can be estimated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Turbulent secondary flows are naturally or artificially induced flows perpendicular to the main direction of primary flow. Many important industrial processes have curved-pipe systems and rotating machinery designed to enhance and optimize mixing of chemicals and other fluids. These systems may also produce turbulent secondary flows. Depending on how the secondary flow is generated, it may be ordered and stationary in space creating stagnant regions, which inhibits mixing even if the flow has significant turbulence. This research started off with the main aim of providing a better understanding of the physics behind the generation of secondary flows and how to control them through the use of simulations and experiments.

 

For this purpose, we decided to use non-wetting (hydrophobic) surfaces, as they are available commercially and have a series of advantageous side properties, such as reducing the overall drag and energy losses in the flow. Our main aim was to show that non-wetting surfaces were capable of affecting and controlling secondary flows through selectively patterning the solid boundaries. We focused our efforts on studying Taylor-Couette flow, the flow between two co-axial and independently rotating cylinders. This is a well-studied problem in the fluid dynamics field, which has well-characterized secondary flows. In addition to that, Taylor-Couette flow has a very similar geometry to centrifugal mixers and bioreactors.

 

Our research program consisted of a series of steps. First, by using direct numerical simulations, we were able to investigate a wide range of possible shapes and sizes of treatment patterns to determine the most effective variations. We found that patterns oriented in the cross-flow direction (axial patterns), as well as patterns oriented at an angle to the flow (spiral patterns) were the most effective in disrupting the secondary flows.

 

After this, we built the experiment, and used it to study the best geometries as determined by the simulations. We applied a commercially-available treatment to one of the cylinders of the experiment, and found that we could indeed affect the secondary flows if the treatment was carefully applied so that the secondary flows would not change size due to the presence of the treatment. We were able to obtain excellent agreement between experiments and simulations of treated cylinders. This fulfilled the main scientific objective of the proposal: showing that surface treatments which take place at the microscale can affect much larger and turbulent flows.  We were also able to characterize the aging of the treatment to understand how long the treatment would remain effective. This has the potential for drastically increasing the efficiency of certain types of centrifugal mixers and reactors while reducing energy expenditure. By the end of our research, the team filed a patent related to these treatments.

 

This proposal supported a graduate student and an undergraduate student. Three peer-reviewed journal publications and a patent were developed with the financial support provided. We also conducted small-scale events with a local society which promotes diversity in engineering. The experimental apparatus also served for the training of three NSF-RET teachers from underrepresented schools in Houston, Texas, during a single summer.
